shortDescription: A minor change in a design may alter user behaviour in ways that are hard to detect in a usability test. An A/B test allows you to compare real-world user behaviour across different versions of a product.
title: A/B Testing

shortDescription: Detect problems users have with your design and correct these before the product goes live.
title: Usability testing

shortDescription: To get objective data about users' attention and physical state.
title: Biometrics

shortDescription: Understand the reasons behind user behaviour, or uncover the mental models of the user in a usability test.
title: Thinking aloud

shortDescription: Gain insights from real usage statistics in order to continue improving a website, app or social media campaign after it is in use, or monitor it’s use for marketing purposes.
title: Online analytics

shortDescription: A Wizard of Oz: acting out the systems functionality, can help when a system has not been build yet, but a realistic user test is necessary to drive design.
title: Wizard of Oz

shortDescription: Participants never act completely naturally in a lab setting, so consider testing your product in the ‘wild’. This can be particularly valuable when real-life disturbances are important for your design, as is the case with mobile apps.
title: Field Trial

shortDescription: Collect information (mostly quantitative) from a large sample of your target group.
title: Survey

shortDescription: Learn from potential users of your new product and other stakeholders.
title: Interview

shortDescription: Efficiently gather opinions and experiences through group discussions with stakeholders, users or experts.
title: Focus group

shortDescription: Find out what information organisation structures are considered intuitive by users.
title: Card sorting

shortDescription: Report detailed information about routines and long-term experience.
title: Diary study

shortDescription: Sometimes the best design ideas arise from ‘first hand’ experience with the situation you are designing for; so “be the user”.
title: Participant observation

shortDescription: Probes can be used to gather inspirational rather than factual information from users. They give insights in peoples lives, values and thoughts.
title: Cultural probes

shortDescription: Find out how people act in real life by using a non-obtrusive observation technique.
title: Fly on the wall

shortDescription: Complementary to user research, or when user research is too costly, a heuristic evaluation can be used to detect and repair usability errors.
title: Heuristic Evaluation

shortDescription: Ensure the product is perfect before it is released to the client or users.
title: (Product) Quality Review

shortDescription: “With many eye-balls on the code, all bugs are shallow.” Colleagues and experts can help position and improve your work, certainly if it needs to be reused by them.
title: Peer Review

shortDescription: In a competitive business situation you need to be able to identify and communicate clearly and concisely what it is that sets you apart.
title: USP (Unique Selling Points)

shortDescription: Friendly provocation can help uncover hidden values and requirements from your stakeholders.
title: Provocative Prototyping

shortDescription: Involve stakeholders and other experts early in the design process in order to set an innovative direction and to create openness for novel ideas among stakeholders.
title: Co-reflection

shortDescription: By placing your work in the spotlight, you learn about its value for others in ways you might not expect yourself.
title: Expo

shortDescription: Develop, evaluate or communicate a concept, design or problem solution to make your ideas concrete, to learn whether they work and to discover the technical limitations or possibilities.
title: Prototyping

shortDescription: Gain inspiration from your users by involving them in the design process. Co-creation may lead to unexpected and sensible project outcomes.
title: Co-creation

shortDescription: Make abstract concepts concrete and strengthen the empathy for the user in your team by using storytelling.
title: Storytelling

shortDescription: Explore and communicate forms and ideas.
title: Sketching

shortDescription: Generate and develop new ideas.
title: Ideation

shortDescription: Come up with novel idea's based on technical opportunities and affordances.
title: Tinkering

shortDescription: When it is hard to develop an initial idea into an elegant solution, a morphological technique such as scamper can help.
title: Scamper

shortDescription: Demonstrate the desirability or the feasibility of your idea or design.
title: Proof of Concept

shortDescription: Generating ideas in a systematic manner.
title: Morphological chart

shortDescription: Find a niche or unique selling point competitors are not filling.
title: Competitive analysis

shortDescription: Find general information, guidance and best practices.
title: Literature study

shortDescription: Incorporating what has proven to work somewhere else forms the basis of any high-quality project.
title: Best good and bad practices

shortDescription: A domain expert can put you on the right track when you enter a new domain or field of expertise. The expert can recommend sources, give you a sense of direction or point out common pitfalls.
title: Expert interview

shortDescription: Applying well-known design patterns improves the quality (and structure) of the designed software.
title: Design pattern research

shortDescription: Existing products in your niche can be a valuable reference and source of inspiration.
title: Benchmark creation

shortDescription: Catch up with novel developments before your competitors do.
title: Trend analysis

shortDescription: To specify a series of events to observe the behaviour of the developed solution.
title: Scenario

shortDescription: To create a starting point for design choices during the project, and to measure whether the project succeeded.
title: Requirement list

shortDescription: Develop a structured visualisation of how a new company can reach its customers and earn revenue in order to understand, discuss, create, and analyse a new business idea.
title: Business model canvas

shortDescription: A comparison chart, or comparison table, describes and compares attributes and characteristics of existing products or tools in order to determine the best option for your project.
title: Comparison chart

shortDescription: When you develop a new product or service, the concept summarizes 'the big idea' or 'the main principle' on which your solution will be based. For example, most traditional churches have a floor plan based on a cross so God can recognize a church from the sky. Validate your concept(s) with stakeholders to determine desirability and feasibility.
title: Concept

shortDescription: Describe the characteristics of a product, like a website or an application, in order to inform the designers and developers who are involved.
title: Design specification

shortDescription: Before you start to make a design, a mood board can help describe the ‘mood’ or the ‘feel’ of the envisioned product.
title: Mood board

shortDescription: Summarize and synthetize findings from observations and interviews in a structured way. Empathy maps can offer valuable and unexpected insights in the user.
title: Empathy map

shortDescription: Represent the user in discussions about the design in an elegant way.
title: Persona

shortDescription: Visualize the user experience of a service over time and across the different interaction moments (touch points) within the service.
title: Customer journey

shortDescription: Save and organize creative ideas during a project, or even permanently, in order to have access to them very quickly and let ideas ‘simmer’ for a while.
title: Inspiration wall

shortDescription: When your product has to support people performing some kind of task (for example repairing a car), a task analysis will help you and other designers understand the task better.
title: Task analysis

shortDescription: Determine which risks are acceptable by making an inventory of the possible threats in a project and determining the probability and impact of each threat. Possibly also determine the effect in, for example, terms of costs.
title: Risk analysis
